# Sachin Tendulkar

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

"Tendulkar" redirects here. For other people with the same surname, see
[Tendulkar (surname)](/wiki/Tendulkar_\(surname\) "Tendulkar \(surname\)").

For the film based on the life of Sachin Tendulkar, see [Sachin: A Billion
Dreams](/wiki/Sachin:_A_Billion_Dreams "Sachin: A Billion Dreams").

**Sachin Ramesh Tendulkar** ([/ˌsətʃɪn tɛnˈduːlkər/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English
"Help:IPA/English") ([![About this
sound](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-
Loudspeaker.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Sachin_Tendulkar.ogg "About this sound")
[listen](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/11/Sachin_Tendulkar.ogg
"Sachin Tendulkar.ogg")); born 24 April 1973) is a former
[Indian](/wiki/Indian_people "Indian people") [cricketer](/wiki/Cricket
"Cricket") and a former
[captain](/wiki/List_of_India_national_cricket_captains "List of India
national cricket captains"), widely regarded as the greatest
[batsman](/wiki/Batting_\(cricket\) "Batting \(cricket\)") of all time.[4] The
highest run scorer of all time in [International
cricket](/wiki/International_cricket "International cricket"), Tendulkar took
up cricket at the age of eleven, made his [Test](/wiki/Test_cricket "Test
cricket") debut on 15 November 1989 against
[Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan_national_cricket_team "Pakistan national cricket
team") in [Karachi](/wiki/Karachi "Karachi") at the age of sixteen, and went
on to represent [Mumbai](/wiki/Mumbai_cricket_team "Mumbai cricket team")
domestically and [India](/wiki/Indian_cricket_team "Indian cricket team")
internationally for close to twenty-four years. He is the only player to have
[scored one hundred international
centuries](/wiki/List_of_cricketers_by_number_of_international_centuries_scored
"List of cricketers by number of international centuries scored"), the first
batsman to score a [double century](/wiki/Century_\(cricket\) "Century
\(cricket\)") in a [One Day International](/wiki/One_Day_International "One
Day International"), the holder of the record for the most number of runs in
both [ODI](/wiki/One_Day_International "One Day International") and
[Test](/wiki/Test_cricket "Test cricket") cricket, and the only player to
complete more than 30,000 [runs](/wiki/Run_\(cricket\) "Run \(cricket\)") in
[international cricket](/wiki/International_cricket "International
cricket").[5]

In 2002, halfway through his career, _[Wisden Cricketers'
Almanack](/wiki/Wisden_Cricketers%27_Almanack "Wisden Cricketers' Almanack")_
ranked him the second greatest Test batsman of all time, behind [Don
Bradman](/wiki/Don_Bradman "Don Bradman"), and the second greatest ODI batsman
of all time, behind [Viv Richards](/wiki/Viv_Richards "Viv Richards").[6]
Later in his career, Tendulkar was a part of the Indian team that won the
[2011 World Cup](/wiki/2011_Cricket_World_Cup "2011 Cricket World Cup"), his
first win in six [World Cup](/wiki/Cricket_World_Cup "Cricket World Cup")
appearances for India.[7] He had previously been named "Player of the
Tournament" at the [2003 edition of the
tournament](/wiki/2003_Cricket_World_Cup "2003 Cricket World Cup"), held in
South Africa. In 2013, he was the only Indian cricketer included in an all-
time Test World XI named to mark the 150th anniversary of _Wisden Cricketers '
Almanack_.[8][9][10]

Tendulkar received the [Arjuna Award](/wiki/Arjuna_Award "Arjuna Award") in
1994 for his outstanding sporting achievement, the [Rajiv Gandhi Khel
Ratna](/wiki/Rajiv_Gandhi_Khel_Ratna "Rajiv Gandhi Khel Ratna") award in 1997,
India's highest sporting honour, and the [Padma Shri](/wiki/Padma_Shri "Padma
Shri") and [Padma Vibhushan](/wiki/Padma_Vibhushan "Padma Vibhushan") awards
in 1999 and 2008, respectively, India's fourth and second highest civilian
awards.[11] After a few hours of his final match on 16 November 2013, the
[Prime Minister's Office](/wiki/Prime_Minister%27s_Office_\(India\) "Prime
Minister's Office \(India\)") announced the decision to award him the [Bharat
Ratna](/wiki/Bharat_Ratna "Bharat Ratna"), India's highest civilian
award.[12][13] He is the youngest recipient to date and the first ever
sportsperson to receive the award.[14][15] He also won the 2010 [Sir Garfield
Sobers Trophy](/wiki/Sir_Garfield_Sobers_Trophy "Sir Garfield Sobers Trophy")
for cricketer of the year at the ICC awards.[16] In 2012, Tendulkar was
nominated to the [Rajya Sabha](/wiki/Rajya_Sabha "Rajya Sabha"), the upper
house of the [Parliament of India](/wiki/Parliament_of_India "Parliament of
India").[17] He was also the first sportsperson and the first person without
an aviation background to be awarded the honorary rank of [group
captain](/wiki/Group_captain "Group captain") by the [Indian Air
Force](/wiki/Indian_Air_Force "Indian Air Force").[18] In 2012, he was named
an Honorary [Member of the Order of
Australia](/wiki/Member_of_the_Order_of_Australia "Member of the Order of
Australia").[19][20]

In December 2012, Tendulkar announced his retirement from ODIs.[21] He retired
from Twenty20 cricket in October 2013[22] and subsequently retired from all
forms of cricket on 16 November 2013 after playing his [200th Test
match](/wiki/West_Indian_cricket_team_in_India_in_2013%E2%80%9314#Second_Test
"West Indian cricket team in India in 2013–14"), against the [West
Indies](/wiki/West_Indies_cricket_team "West Indies cricket team") in Mumbai's
[Wankhede Stadium](/wiki/Wankhede_Stadium "Wankhede Stadium").[23] Tendulkar
played 664 international cricket matches in total, scoring 34,357 runs.[5]

## Early years

Tendulkar was born at Nirmal Nursing Home in [Dadar](/wiki/Dadar "Dadar"),
[Bombay](/wiki/Mumbai "Mumbai") on 24 April 1973.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] His
father, [Ramesh Tendulkar](/wiki/Ramesh_Tendulkar "Ramesh Tendulkar"), was a
well-known [Marathi](/wiki/Marathi_language "Marathi language") novelist and
his mother, Rajni, worked in the insurance industry.[24] Ramesh named
Tendulkar after his favourite music director, [Sachin Dev
Burman](/wiki/Sachin_Dev_Burman "Sachin Dev Burman"). Tendulkar has three
elder siblings: two half-brothers Nitin and Ajit, and a half-sister Savita.
They were Ramesh's children from his first marriage.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Tendulkar played as a youngster with his brother, Ajit, for Sahitya Sahawas
society’s cricket team at Bandra East. Ajit is credited by Sachin for playing
a pivotal role in his life.[25] [Ramakant Achrekar](/wiki/Ramakant_Achrekar
"Ramakant Achrekar") was impressed with Tendulkar's talent and advised him to
shift his schooling to Sharadashram Vidyamandir (English) High School,[1] a
school at Dadar which had a dominant cricket team and had produced many
notable cricketers. Prior to this, Tendulkar had attended the Indian Education
Society's New English School in Bandra (East).[26] He was also coached under
the guidance of Achrekar at Shivaji Park in the mornings and evenings.[27]
Tendulkar would practice for hours on end in the nets. If he became exhausted,
Achrekar would put a one-[rupee](/wiki/Indian_rupee "Indian rupee") coin on
the top of the [stumps](/wiki/Stumps "Stumps"), and the bowler who dismissed
Tendulkar would get the coin. If Tendulkar passed the whole session without
getting dismissed, the coach would give him the coin. Tendulkar now considers
the 13 coins he won then as some of his most prized possessions.[28] He moved
in with his aunt and uncle, who lived near Shivaji Park, during this period,
due to his hectic schedule.[26]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Anjali-
Sachin.jpg/220px-Anjali-Sachin.jpg)](/wiki/File:Anjali-Sachin.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Anjali-Sachin.jpg "Enlarge")

Sachin Tendulkar and his wife Anjali

Meanwhile, at school, he developed a reputation as a child prodigy. He had
become a common conversation point in local cricketing circles, where there
were suggestions already that he would become one of the greats. Sachin
consistently featured in the school team in the Matunga Gujarati Seva Mandal
(MGSM) Shield.[29] Besides school cricket, he also played club cricket,
initially representing John Bright Cricket Club in Bombay's premier club
cricket tournament, the Kanga League,[26] and later went on to play for the
[Cricket Club of India](/wiki/Cricket_Club_of_India "Cricket Club of
India").[30] In 1987, at the age of 14, he attended the [MRF Pace
Foundation](/wiki/MRF_Pace_Foundation "MRF Pace Foundation") in Madras (now
[Chennai](/wiki/Chennai "Chennai")) to train as a [fast
bowler](/wiki/Fast_bowler "Fast bowler"), but Australian fast bowler [Dennis
Lillee](/wiki/Dennis_Lillee "Dennis Lillee"), who took a world record 355 Test
wickets, was unimpressed, suggesting that Tendulkar focus on his batting
instead.[31] On 20 January 1987, he also turned out as substitute for [Imran
Khan](/wiki/Imran_Khan "Imran Khan")'s side in an exhibition game at Brabourne
Stadium in Bombay, to mark the golden jubilee of [Cricket Club of
India](/wiki/Cricket_Club_of_India "Cricket Club of India").[32] A couple of
months later, former Indian batsman [Sunil Gavaskar](/wiki/Sunil_Gavaskar
"Sunil Gavaskar") gave him a pair of his own ultra light pads and consoled him
to not get disheartened for not getting the Bombay Cricket Association's "Best
junior cricket award" (He was 14 years that time). "It was the greatest source
of encouragement for me," Tendulkar said nearly 20 years later after
surpassing Gavaskar's world record of 34 Test centuries.[33][34] Sachin served
as a [ball boy](/wiki/Ball_boy "Ball boy") in the [1987 Cricket World
Cup](/wiki/1987_Cricket_World_Cup "1987 Cricket World Cup") when India played
against England in the semifinal in Bombay.[35][36] In his season in 1988,
Tendulkar scored a century in every innings he played. He was involved in an
unbroken 664-run [partnership](/wiki/Partnership_\(cricket\) "Partnership
\(cricket\)") in a Lord Harris Shield inter-school game against St. Xavier's
High School in 1988 with his friend and teammate [Vinod
Kambli](/wiki/Vinod_Kambli "Vinod Kambli"), who would also go on to represent
India. The destructive pair reduced one bowler to tears and made the rest of
the opposition unwilling to continue the game. Tendulkar scored 326 (not out)
in this innings and scored over a thousand runs in the tournament.[37] This
was a record partnership in any form of cricket until 2006, when it was broken
by two under-13 batsmen in a match held at [Hyderabad](/wiki/Hyderabad,_India
"Hyderabad, India") in India.[38]

## Early domestic career

On 14 November 1987, Tendulkar was selected to represent
[Bombay](/wiki/Mumbai_cricket_team "Mumbai cricket team") in the [Ranji
Trophy](/wiki/Ranji_Trophy "Ranji Trophy"), India's premier domestic [First-
class cricket](/wiki/First-class_cricket "First-class cricket") tournament,
for the 1987–88 season. However, he was not selected for the final eleven in
any of the matches, though he was often used as a substitute fielder.[26] He
narrowly missed out on playing alongside his idol Gavaskar, who had retired
from all forms of cricket after the [1987 Cricket World
Cup](/wiki/1987_Cricket_World_Cup "1987 Cricket World Cup").[26] A year later,
on 11 December 1988, aged 15 years and 232 days, Tendulkar made his debut for
Bombay against [Gujarat](/wiki/Gujarat_cricket_team "Gujarat cricket team") at
home and scored 100 not out in that match, making him the youngest Indian to
score a century on debut in first-class cricket.[39] He was handpicked to play
for the team by the then Bombay captain [Dilip
Vengsarkar](/wiki/Dilip_Vengsarkar "Dilip Vengsarkar") after watching him
easily negotiating India's best fast bowler at the time, [Kapil
Dev](/wiki/Kapil_Dev "Kapil Dev"), in the [Wankhede
Stadium](/wiki/Wankhede_Stadium "Wankhede Stadium") nets,[1] where the [Indian
team](/wiki/India_national_cricket_team "India national cricket team") had
come to play against the touring [New Zealand
team](/wiki/New_Zealand_national_cricket_team "New Zealand national cricket
team"). He followed this by scoring a century in his first
[Deodhar](/wiki/Deodhar_Trophy "Deodhar Trophy") and [Duleep
Trophies](/wiki/Duleep_Trophy "Duleep Trophy"), which are also Indian domestic
tournaments.[40]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Dnyaneshwar_Agashe_with_Sachin_Tendulkar.png/220px-
Dnyaneshwar_Agashe_with_Sachin_Tendulkar.png)](/wiki/File:Dnyaneshwar_Agashe_with_Sachin_Tendulkar.png)

[](/wiki/File:Dnyaneshwar_Agashe_with_Sachin_Tendulkar.png "Enlarge")

Tendulkar (left) with former [Vice president](/wiki/Vice_president "Vice
president") of [BCCI](/wiki/Board_of_Control_for_Cricket_in_India "Board of
Control for Cricket in India"), late [Dnyaneshwar
Agashe](/wiki/Dnyaneshwar_Agashe "Dnyaneshwar Agashe") (center) and [Sourav
Ganguly](/wiki/Sourav_Ganguly "Sourav Ganguly") (right)

Tendulkar finished the 1988–89 season as Bombay's highest run-scorer. He
scored 583 runs at an average of 67.77, and was the sixth highest run-scorer
overall[41] He also made an unbeaten century in the [Irani
Trophy](/wiki/Irani_Trophy "Irani Trophy") match against
[Delhi](/wiki/Delhi_cricket_team "Delhi cricket team") at the start of the
1989–90 season, playing for the Rest of India.[42] Sachin was picked for a
young Indian team to tour England twice, under the Star Cricket Club banner in
1988 and 1989.[43] In the famous 1990–91 Ranji Trophy final, in which
[Haryana](/wiki/Haryana_cricket_team "Haryana cricket team") defeated Bombay
by two runs after leading in the first innings, Tendulkar's 96 from 75
deliveries was a key to giving Bombay a chance of victory as it attempted to
chase 355 from only 70 overs on the final day.[44]

His first double century (204*) was for Mumbai while playing against the
visiting Australian team at the [Brabourne Stadium](/wiki/Brabourne_Stadium
"Brabourne Stadium") in 1998.[1][45] He is the only player to score a century
on debut in all three of his domestic first-class tournaments (the Ranji,
Irani, and Duleep Trophies).[46] Another double century was an innings of 233*
against [Tamil Nadu](/wiki/Tamil_Nadu_cricket_team "Tamil Nadu cricket team")
in the semi-finals of the 2000 [Ranji Trophy](/wiki/Ranji_Trophy "Ranji
Trophy"), which he regards as one of the best innings of his
career.[47][48][49]

### Yorkshire

In 1992, at the age of 19, Tendulkar became the first overseas-born player to
represent [Yorkshire](/wiki/Yorkshire_County_Cricket_Club "Yorkshire County
Cricket Club"), which prior to Tendulkar joining the team, never selected
players even from other English counties.[1][Note 1] Selected for Yorkshire as
a replacement for the injured
[Australian](/wiki/Australia_national_cricket_team "Australia national cricket
team") fast bowler [Craig McDermott](/wiki/Craig_McDermott "Craig McDermott"),
Tendulkar played 16 first-class matches for the county and scored 1070 runs at
an average of 46.52.[50]

## International career

### Early career

[Raj Singh Dungarpur](/wiki/Raj_Singh_Dungarpur "Raj Singh Dungarpur") is
credited for the selection of Tendulkar for the Indian tour of
[Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan_national_cricket_team "Pakistan national cricket
team") in late 1989,[51] after one first class season.[52] The Indian
selection committee had shown interest in selecting Tendulkar for the [tour of
the West Indies](/wiki/Indian_cricket_team_in_West_Indies_in_1988%E2%80%9389
"Indian cricket team in West Indies in 1988–89") held earlier that year, but
eventually did not select him, as they did not want him to be exposed to the
dominant fast bowlers of the West Indies so early in his career. Tendulkar
made his [Test](/wiki/Test_cricket "Test cricket") debut against Pakistan in
[Karachi in November
1989](/wiki/Indian_cricket_team_in_Pakistan_in_1989%E2%80%9390 "Indian cricket
team in Pakistan in 1989–90") aged 16 years and 205 days. He made 15 runs,
being bowled by [Waqar Younis](/wiki/Waqar_Younis "Waqar Younis"), who also
made his debut in that match, but was noted for how he handled numerous blows
to his body at the hands of the Pakistani pace attack.[53] In the fourth and
final Test in [Sialkot](/wiki/Sialkot "Sialkot"), he was hit on the nose by a
bouncer bowled by Younis, but he declined medical assistance and continued to
bat even as he gushed blood from it.[54] In a 20-over exhibition game in
[Peshawar](/wiki/Peshawar "Peshawar"), held in parallel with the bilateral
series, Tendulkar made 53 runs off 18 balls, including an over in which he
scored 27 runs (6, 4, 0, 6, 6, 6) off leg-spinner [Abdul
Qadir](/wiki/Abdul_Qadir_\(cricketer\) "Abdul Qadir \(cricketer\)").[55] This
was later called "one of the best innings I have seen" by the then Indian
captain [Krishnamachari Srikkanth](/wiki/Krishnamachari_Srikkanth
"Krishnamachari Srikkanth").[56] In all, he scored 215 runs at an average of
35.83 in the Test series, and was dismissed without scoring a run in the only
[One Day International](/wiki/One_Day_International "One Day International")
(ODI) he played.[57][58] Thus Sachin Tendulkar became the youngest player to
debut for India in [Tests](/wiki/Test_cricket "Test cricket") at the age of 16
years and 205 days and also the youngest player to debut for India in
[ODIs](/wiki/One_Day_International "One Day International") at the age of 16
years and 238 days.[59][60]

The series was followed by a tour of New Zealand in which he scored 117 runs
at an average of 29.25 in Tests including an innings of 88 in the second
Test.[61] He was dismissed without scoring in one of the two one-day games he
played, and scored 36 in the other.[62] On his next tour, a summer tour to
England of 1990, on 14 August, he became the second youngest cricketer to
score a Test century as he made 119 not out in the second Test at [Old
Trafford](/wiki/Old_Trafford_\(cricket_ground\) "Old Trafford \(cricket
ground\)") in Manchester, an innings which contributed to a draw and saved
India from certain defeat in the match.[54] [Wisden](/wiki/Wisden "Wisden")
described his innings as "a disciplined display of immense maturity" and also
wrote:[63]

> He looked the embodiment of India's famous opener, Gavaskar, and indeed was
> wearing a pair of his pads. While he displayed a full repertoire of strokes
> in compiling his maiden Test hundred, most remarkable were his off-side
> shots from the back foot. Though only 5ft 5in tall, he was still able to
> control without difficulty short deliveries from the English pacemen.

Tendulkar further enhanced his reputation as a future great during the 1991–92
tour of Australia held before the [1992 Cricket World
Cup](/wiki/1992_Cricket_World_Cup "1992 Cricket World Cup"), that included an
unbeaten 148 in the third Test at [Sydney](/wiki/Sydney_Cricket_Ground "Sydney
Cricket Ground"), making him the youngest batsman to score a century in
Australia. He then scored 114 on a fast, bouncing pitch in the final Test at
[Perth](/wiki/WACA_Ground "WACA Ground") against a pace attack comprising
[Merv Hughes](/wiki/Merv_Hughes "Merv Hughes"), [Bruce Reid](/wiki/Bruce_Reid
"Bruce Reid") and [Craig McDermott](/wiki/Craig_McDermott "Craig McDermott").
Hughes commented to [Allan Border](/wiki/Allan_Border "Allan Border") at the
time that "This little prick's going to get more runs than you, AB."[64]

### Rise through the ranks

Tendulkar's performance through the years 1994–1999 coincided with his
physical peak, in his early twenties. He opened the batting at
[Auckland](/wiki/Auckland "Auckland") against New Zealand in 1994, making 82
runs off 49 balls. He scored his first ODI century on 9 September 1994 against
Australia in [Sri Lanka](/wiki/Sri_Lanka "Sri Lanka") at
[Colombo](/wiki/Colombo "Colombo").[65][66] It took him 78 ODIs to score his
first century.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Sachin_at_the_other_end.jpg/220px-
Sachin_at_the_other_end.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sachin_at_the_other_end.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Sachin_at_the_other_end.jpg "Enlarge")

Tendulkar waits at the bowler's end.

Tendulkar's rise continued when he was the leading run scorer at the [1996
World Cup](/wiki/1996_Cricket_World_Cup "1996 Cricket World Cup"), scoring two
centuries.[67] He was the only Indian batsman to perform well in the semi-
final against Sri Lanka. Tendulkar fell amid a batting collapse and the match
referee, [Clive Lloyd](/wiki/Clive_Lloyd "Clive Lloyd"), awarded Sri Lanka the
match after the crowd began rioting and throwing litter onto the field.[68]

After the World Cup, in the same year against Pakistan at
[Sharjah](/wiki/Sharjah_\(city\) "Sharjah \(city\)"), Indian captain [Mohammed
Azharuddin](/wiki/Mohammed_Azharuddin "Mohammed Azharuddin") was going through
a lean patch. Tendulkar and [Navjot Singh Sidhu](/wiki/Navjot_Singh_Sidhu
"Navjot Singh Sidhu") both made centuries to set a then record partnership for
the second wicket. After getting out, Tendulkar found Azharuddin in two minds
about whether he should bat.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
Tendulkar convinced Azharuddin to bat and Azharuddin subsequently unleashed 24
runs off one over.[69] India went on to win that match. It enabled India to
post a score in excess of 300 runs for the first time in an ODI.[70]

This was the beginning of a period at the top of the batting world,
culminating in the Australian tour of India in early 1998, with Tendulkar
scoring three consecutive centuries. The focus was on the clash between
Tendulkar, the world's most dominating batsman and [Shane
Warne](/wiki/Shane_Warne "Shane Warne"), the world's leading spinner, both at
the peak of their careers, clashing in a Test series.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] In the
lead-up to the series, Tendulkar simulated scenarios in the nets with [Laxman
Sivaramakrishnan](/wiki/Laxman_Sivaramakrishnan "Laxman Sivaramakrishnan"),
the former India leg spinner, donning the role of Warne.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] In
their tour opener, Australia faced the then Ranji Champions Mumbai at the
[Brabourne Stadium](/wiki/Brabourne_Stadium "Brabourne Stadium") in a three-
day first class match.[71] Tendulkar made an unbeaten 204 as Shane Warne
conceded 111 runs in 16 overs and Australia lost the match within three
days.[72][73] He also had a role with the ball in the five-match ODI series in
India following the Tests, including a five wicket haul in an ODI in
[Kochi](/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru_Stadium,_Kochi "Jawaharlal Nehru Stadium,
Kochi"). Set 310 runs to win, Australia were cruising at 203 for 3 in the 31st
over when Tendulkar turned the match for India, taking the wickets of [Michael
Bevan](/wiki/Michael_Bevan "Michael Bevan"), [Steve Waugh](/wiki/Steve_Waugh
"Steve Waugh"), [Darren Lehmann](/wiki/Darren_Lehmann "Darren Lehmann"), [Tom
Moody](/wiki/Tom_Moody "Tom Moody") and [Damien Martyn](/wiki/Damien_Martyn
"Damien Martyn") for 32 runs in 10 overs.[74] The Test match success was
followed by two consecutive centuries in April 1998 in a Triangular cricket
[tournament](/wiki/1998_Coca-Cola_Cup "1998 Coca-Cola Cup") in Sharjah – the
first in a must-win game to take India to the finals and then again in the
finals, both against Australia. These twin knocks were also known as the
[Desert Storm](/wiki/1997%E2%80%9398_Coca-Cola_Cup "1997–98 Coca-Cola Cup")
innings.[75] Following the series, Warne ruefully joked that he was having
nightmares about his Indian nemesis.[76]

Tendulkar's contribution in the ICC 1998 quarterfinal at [Dhaka](/wiki/Dhaka
"Dhaka") paved the way for India's entry into the semifinals, when he took
four Australian wickets after scoring 141 runs in 128 balls.[77]

The inaugural [Asian Test Championship](/wiki/Asian_Test_Championship "Asian
Test Championship") took place in [February and March
1999](/wiki/1998%E2%80%9399_Asian_Test_Championship "1998–99 Asian Test
Championship"), involving India, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka.[78] In the first
match, between India and Pakistan in Eden Gardens, Tendulkar was run out for
nine after colliding with Pakistan bowler [Shoaib Akhtar](/wiki/Shoaib_Akhtar
"Shoaib Akhtar"). Around 100,000 people came to support India during the
initial four days of the tournament, breaking a 63-year-old record for
aggregate Test attendance record.[79] The crowd's reaction to Tendulkar's
dismissal was to throw objects at Akhtar, and the players were taken off the
field. The match resumed after Tendulkar and the president of the ICC appealed
to the crowd; however, further rioting meant that the match was finished in
front of a crowd of 200 people.[80] Tendulkar scored his 19th Test century in
the second Test and the match resulted in a draw with Sri Lanka.[81] India did
not progress to the final, which was won by Pakistan, and refused to
participate the next time the championship was held due to increasing
political tensions between India and Pakistan.[82]

In the Test against Pakistan at [Chepauk](/wiki/Chepauk "Chepauk") in 1999,
the first of a two-Test series, Sachin scored 136 in the fourth innings with
India chasing 271 for victory. However, he was out when India needed 17 more
runs to win, triggering a batting collapse, and India lost the match by 12
runs.[83] The worst was yet to come as Professor Ramesh Tendulkar, Sachin's
father, died in the middle of the [1999 Cricket World
Cup](/wiki/1999_Cricket_World_Cup "1999 Cricket World Cup"). Tendulkar flew
back to India to attend the final rituals of his father, missing the match
against [Zimbabwe](/wiki/Zimbabwe "Zimbabwe").[84] However, he returned to the
World Cup scoring a century (140 not out off 101 balls) in his very next match
against [Kenya](/wiki/Kenya_national_cricket_team "Kenya national cricket
team") in Bristol. He dedicated this century to his father.[85]

### Captaincy

**Tendulkar 's record as captain**  
---  
| Matches | Won | Lost | Drawn | Tied | No result | Win %  
Test[86] | 25 | 4 | 9 | 12 | 0 | – | 16%  
ODI[87] | 73 | 23 | 43 | – | 2 | 6 | 31.50%  
  
Tendulkar's two tenures as captain of the Indian cricket team were not very
successful. When Tendulkar took over as captain in 1996, it was with huge
hopes and expectations. However, by 1997 the team was performing poorly.
[Azharuddin](/wiki/Mohammad_Azharuddin "Mohammad Azharuddin") was credited
with saying _" Nahin jeetega! Chote ki naseeb main jeet nahin hai!"_,[88]
which translates into: "He won't win! It's not in the small one's
destiny!".[89]

Tendulkar, succeeding Azharuddin as captain for his second term, led India on
a tour of Australia, where the visitors were beaten 3–0 by the newly crowned
world champions.[90] Tendulkar, however, won the player of the series
award[90] as well as player of the match in one of the games.[91] After
another Test series defeat, this time by a 0–2 margin at home against South
Africa, Tendulkar resigned, and [Sourav Ganguly](/wiki/Sourav_Ganguly "Sourav
Ganguly") took over as captain in 2000.[92][93]

During the Indian team's 2007 tour of England, the desire of [Rahul
Dravid](/wiki/Rahul_Dravid "Rahul Dravid") to resign from the captaincy became
known. The BCCI President [Sharad Pawar](/wiki/Sharad_Pawar "Sharad Pawar")
offered the captaincy to Tendulkar, who instead recommended [Mahendra Singh
Dhoni](/wiki/Mahendra_Singh_Dhoni "Mahendra Singh Dhoni") to take over the
reins. Pawar later revealed this conversation, crediting Tendulkar for first
forwarding the name of Dhoni, who since achieved much success as captain.[94]

### Mike Denness incident

Main article: [Mike Denness and Indian cricket team
incident](/wiki/Mike_Denness_and_Indian_cricket_team_incident "Mike Denness
and Indian cricket team incident")

In India's 2001 tour of South Africa in the second [test
match](/wiki/Test_Cricket "Test Cricket") between
[India](/wiki/Indian_cricket_team "Indian cricket team") and [South
Africa](/wiki/South_African_cricket_team "South African cricket team") at [St
George's Park](/wiki/Sahara_Oval_St_George%27s "Sahara Oval St George's"),
[Port Elizabeth](/wiki/Port_Elizabeth "Port Elizabeth"), match referee [Mike
Denness](/wiki/Mike_Denness "Mike Denness") fined four Indian players for
excessive appealing, as well as fined the Indian captain [Sourav
Ganguly](/wiki/Sourav_Ganguly "Sourav Ganguly") for not controlling his
team.[95] Tendulkar was given a suspended ban of one game by Denness in light
of alleged [ball tampering](/wiki/Ball_tampering "Ball tampering"). Television
cameras picked up images that suggested Tendulkar may have been involved in
cleaning the seam of the cricket ball.[96] This can, under some conditions,
amount to altering the condition of the ball. Denness found Sachin Tendulkar
guilty of ball tampering charges and handed him a one Test match ban.[97] The
incident escalated to include sports journalists accusing Denness of
racism,[98] and led to Denness being barred from entering the venue of the
third Test match. The ICC revoked the status of the match as a Test as the
teams rejected the appointed referee.[99] The charges against Tendulkar and
Sehwag's ban for excessive appealing triggered a massive backlash from the
Indian public.[100]

### Injuries and decline amid surpassing Bradman's haul

Sachin Tendulkar continued performing well in Test cricket in 2001 and 2002,
with some pivotal performances with both bat and ball. Tendulkar took three
wickets on the final day of the famous [Kolkata Test against Australia in
2001](/wiki/Second_Test,_2000%E2%80%9301_Border%E2%80%93Gavaskar_Trophy
"Second Test, 2000–01 Border–Gavaskar Trophy"). Tendulkar took the key wickets
of [Matthew Hayden](/wiki/Matthew_Hayden "Matthew Hayden") and [Adam
Gilchrist](/wiki/Adam_Gilchrist "Adam Gilchrist"), who were centurions in the
previous Test.He also take a wicket of [Shane Warne](/wiki/Shane_Warne "Shane
Warne").This three wicket change the result of test match from draw to win of
India.[101] In the five-match ODI series that followed, he took his 100th
wicket in ODIs, claiming the wicket of then Australian captain [Steve
Waugh](/wiki/Steve_Waugh "Steve Waugh") in the final match at the [Fatorda
Stadium](/wiki/Fatorda_Stadium "Fatorda Stadium") in [Goa](/wiki/Goa
"Goa").[102]

In the 2002 series in the West Indies, Tendulkar started well, scoring 79 in
the first Test. In the second Test at Port of Spain, Sachin Tendulkar scored
117 in the first innings, his 29th Test century in his 93rd Test match, to
equal Sir [Donald Bradman](/wiki/Donald_Bradman "Donald Bradman")'s record of
29 Test hundreds.He was awarded by Sports car "[Ferrari](/wiki/Ferrari
"Ferrari")" by [Michael Schumacher](/wiki/Michael_Schumacher "Michael
Schumacher") for achieving this feat.[103][104][105]

### Decline phase of career

Then, in a hitherto unprecedented sequence, he scored 0, 0, 8 and 0 in the
next four innings.[106] He returned to form in the last Test scoring 41 and
86, one half century. However, India lost the series.[107] In this period, in
the third Test match against England in August 2002, Sachin scored his 30th
Test century to surpass Bradman's haul, in his 99th Test match.[108][109]

### 2003 Cricket World Cup

Tendulkar made 673 runs in 11 matches in the [2003 Cricket World
Cup](/wiki/2003_Cricket_World_Cup "2003 Cricket World Cup"),[110] helping
India reach the final. While Australia retained the trophy that they had won
in 1999, Tendulkar was given the Man of the Tournament award.[111][112]

He continued to score heavily in ODI cricket that year, with two hundreds in a
tri-series involving New Zealand and Australia.[113][114] As a part-time
bowler, he dismissed an exhausted centurion, Matthew Hayden in the tri-series
final.[115]

### 2003 Tour of Australia

The drawn series as India toured Australia in 2003–04 saw Tendulkar making his
mark in the last Test of the series, with 241 not out from 436 ball by 33 four
at strike rate of 55.27 in [Sydney](/wiki/Sydney_Cricket_Ground "Sydney
Cricket Ground"), putting India in a virtually unbeatable position.He spend
613 minut at crease.India have a first inning score of 705/7. He followed up
the innings with an unbeaten 60 in the second innings of the Test.[116] Prior
to this Test match, he had had an unusually horrible run of form, failing in
all six innings in the preceding three Tests.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] It was
no aberration that 2003 was his worst year in Test cricket, with an average of
17.25 and just one fifty.[117][_[better source needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS
"Wikipedia:NOTRS")_]

Tendulkar scored an unbeaten 194 against Pakistan at [Multan](/wiki/Multan
"Multan") in the following series. Indian captain Rahul Dravid declared before
Tendulkar reached 200; had he done so it would have been the fourth time he
had passed the landmark in Tests.[118] Tendulkar said that he was disappointed
and that the declaration had taken him by surprise.[119] Many former
cricketers commented that Dravid's declaration was in bad taste.[120][121]
After the match, which India won, Dravid said that the matter had been
discussed internally and put to rest.[122]

A [tennis elbow](/wiki/Tennis_elbow "Tennis elbow") injury then took its toll
on Tendulkar, leaving him out of the side for most of the year, coming back
only for the last two Tests when [Australia](/wiki/Australian_cricket_team
"Australian cricket team") toured India in 2004.[123][124] He played a part in
India's victory in Mumbai in that series with a fast 55, though Australia took
the series 2–1.[125]

On 10 December 2005 at [Feroz Shah Kotla](/wiki/Feroz_Shah_Kotla "Feroz Shah
Kotla"), Tendulkar scored his record-breaking 35th Test century, against the
[Sri Lankans](/wiki/Sri_Lankan_cricket_team "Sri Lankan cricket team"). After
this, Tendulkar endured the longest[_[needs
update](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_] spell of his career without a
Test century: 17 innings elapsed before he scored 101 against Bangladesh in
May 2007.[126] Tendulkar scored his 39th ODI hundred on 6 February 2006 in a
match against Pakistan.[127] He followed with a 42 in the second One-Day
International against Pakistan on 11 February 2006,[128] and then a 95 in
hostile, seaming conditions on 13 February 2006 in Lahore, which set up an
Indian victory.[129] On 19 March 2006, after being dismissed for only one run
against [England](/wiki/English_cricket_team "English cricket team") in the
first innings of the third Test in his home ground,
[Wankhede](/wiki/Wankhede_Stadium "Wankhede Stadium"), Tendulkar was booed off
the ground by a section of the crowd,[130] the first time that he had ever
faced such flak. Tendulkar ended the three-Test series without a half-century
to his credit, and the need for a shoulder operation raised more questions
about his longevity.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Tendulkar's comeback came in the DLF cup in [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia
"Malaysia") and he was the only Indian batsman to shine. In his comeback
match, against West Indies on 14 September 2006, Tendulkar responded to his
critics who believed that his career was inexorably sliding with his 40th ODI
century.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Though he scored 141 not out, West Indies won
the rain-affected match by the [D/L method](/wiki/Duckworth-Lewis_method
"Duckworth-Lewis method").[131]

### 2007 Cricket World Cup

During the preparation for the [2007 World Cup](/wiki/2007_Cricket_World_Cup
"2007 Cricket World Cup"), Tendulkar's attitude was criticised by Indian team
coach [Greg Chappell](/wiki/Greg_Chappell "Greg Chappell"). Chappell
reportedly felt that Tendulkar would be more useful down the order, while the
latter felt that he would be better off opening the innings, the role he had
played for most of his career.[132] Chappell also believed that Tendulkar's
repeated failures were hurting the team's chances. In a rare show of emotion,
Tendulkar hit out at the comments attributed to Chappell by pointing out that
no coach had ever suggested his attitude towards cricket was incorrect. On 7
April 2007, the Board of Control for Cricket in India issued a notice to
Tendulkar asking for an explanation for his comments made to the media.[133]
Chappell subsequently resigned as coach but said that this affair had no
bearing on his decision and that he and Tendulkar were on good terms.[132]

At the World Cup in the West Indies, Tendulkar and the Indian cricket team led
by Rahul Dravid had a dismal campaign. Tendulkar, who was pushed to bat lower
down the order had scores of 7 against
[Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh_cricket_team "Bangladesh cricket team"), 57 not
out against [Bermuda](/wiki/Bermuda_cricket_team "Bermuda cricket team") and 0
against [Sri Lanka](/wiki/Sri_Lanka_cricket_team "Sri Lanka cricket
team").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] As a result, former Australian captain [Ian
Chappell](/wiki/Ian_Chappell "Ian Chappell"), brother of Greg, called for
Tendulkar to retire in his newspaper column.[134]

### Return to old form and consistency

See also: [List of batsmen who have scored over 10000 One Day International
cricket
runs](/wiki/List_of_batsmen_who_have_scored_over_10000_One_Day_International_cricket_runs
"List of batsmen who have scored over 10000 One Day International cricket
runs")

In the subsequent Test series against Bangladesh, Tendulkar returned to his
opening slot and was chosen as the Man of the Series.[135] He continued by
scoring 99 and 93 in the first two matches of the Future Cup against South
Africa. During the second match, he also became the first to score 15,000 runs
in ODIs.[136] He was the leading run scorer and was adjudged the Man of the
Series.[137][138]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Tendulkar_closup.jpg/220px-
Tendulkar_closup.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tendulkar_closup.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Tendulkar_closup.jpg "Enlarge")

Tendulkar celebrates upon reaching his 38th Test century against Australia in
the 2nd Test at the [SCG](/wiki/Sydney_Cricket_Ground "Sydney Cricket Ground")
in 2008, where he finished [not out](/wiki/Not_out "Not out") on 154

On the second day of the Nottingham Test on 28 July 2007, Tendulkar became the
third cricketer to complete 11,000 Test runs.[139] In the subsequent one-day
series against England, Tendulkar was the leading run scorer from India[140]
with an average of 53.42. In the ODI Series against Australia in October 2007
Tendulkar was the leading Indian run scorer with 278 runs.[141]

Tendulkar was dismissed seven times in 2007 between 90 and 100, including
three times at 99, leading some to suggestions that he struggles to cope with
nervousness in this phase of his innings.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
Tendulkar has got out 27 times in the 90s during his international
career.[142] In a five-ODI series against Pakistan, he was caught by [Kamran
Akmal](/wiki/Kamran_Akmal "Kamran Akmal") off the bowling of [Umar
Gul](/wiki/Umar_Gul "Umar Gul") for 99 in the second match at
[Mohali](/wiki/Mohali "Mohali"),[143] and in the fourth match of that series,
he got out in the 90s for a second time, scoring 97 before dragging a delivery
from Gul on to his stumps.[144]

### 2007–08 tour of Australia

In the [Border-Gavaskar Trophy,
2007–08](/wiki/Indian_cricket_team_in_Australia_in_2007%E2%80%9308 "Indian
cricket team in Australia in 2007–08"), Tendulkar showed exceptional form,
becoming the leading run scorer with 493 runs in four Tests, despite
consistently failing in the second innings.[145] Sachin scored 62 runs in the
first innings of the first Test at the [MCG](/wiki/Melbourne_Cricket_Ground
"Melbourne Cricket Ground") in [Melbourne](/wiki/Melbourne "Melbourne"), but
could not prevent a heavy 337-run win for Australia.[146] In the
[controversial New Years' Test at
Sydney](/wiki/Second_Test,_2007%E2%80%9308_Border-Gavaskar_Trophy "Second
Test, 2007–08 Border-Gavaskar Trophy"), Tendulkar scored an unbeaten 154, even
though India lost the Test. This was his third century at the
[SCG](/wiki/Sydney_Cricket_Ground "Sydney Cricket Ground") and his 38th Test
century overall, earning him an average of 326 at the ground at the time of
completing the innings.[147][148] In the third Test at the [WACA cricket
ground](/wiki/WACA_Ground "WACA Ground") in
[Perth](/wiki/Perth,_Western_Australia "Perth, Western Australia"), Sachin was
instrumental in India's first innings score of 330, scoring a well-compiled
71. India went on to record a historic triumph at the WACA, ending Australia's
run of 16 consecutive wins.[149] In the fourth Test at the [Adelaide
Oval](/wiki/Adelaide_Oval "Adelaide Oval"), which ended in a draw, he scored
153 in the first innings, being involved in a crucial 126 run stand with
[V.V.S. Laxman](/wiki/V.V.S._Laxman "V.V.S. Laxman") for the fifth wicket to
lead India to a score of 282 for 5 from 156 for 4.[150] He secured the Man of
the Match award.[151]

In the One-Day International Commonwealth Bank Tri-Series involving India, Sri
Lanka and Australia, Tendulkar became the only batsman to complete 16,000 runs
in ODIs.[152] He achieved this feat against Sri Lanka on 5 February 2008 at
the [Gabba](/wiki/The_Gabba "The Gabba") in [Brisbane](/wiki/Brisbane
"Brisbane"). He started the series wth scores of 10, 35, 44 and 32.[153] His
form dipped a bit in the middle of the tournament,[_[original
research?](/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research "Wikipedia:No original
research")_] but Tendulkar came back strongly in India's must-win game against
Sri Lanka at the [Bellerive Oval](/wiki/Bellerive_Oval "Bellerive Oval") in
[Hobart](/wiki/Hobart "Hobart"), scoring 63 off 54 balls.[154] He finished the
series with a match winning 117 not out off 120 balls in the first final,[155]
and 91 runs in the second final.[156]

### Home series against South Africa

**Sachin Tendulkar 's Test cricket record**[157]  
---  
| Matches | Runs | Best | Average | 100s | 50s  
Home | 94 | 7216 | 217 | 52.67 | 22 | 32  
Away | 106 | 8705 | 248* | 54.74 | 29 | 36  
  
South Africa toured in [March and April
2008](/wiki/South_African_cricket_team_in_India_in_2007%E2%80%9308 "South
African cricket team in India in 2007–08") for a three-Test series. Tendulkar
scored a five-ball duck in his only innings of the series;[158] he sustained a
groin strain in the match and as a result was forced not only to miss the
second and third Tests, but also the tri-series involving Bangladesh, the
[2008 Asia Cup](/wiki/2008_Asia_Cup "2008 Asia Cup"), and the first half of
the inaugural season of the [IPL](/wiki/Indian_Premier_League "Indian Premier
League").[159]

### Sri Lanka Series

Before the [Indian cricket team's tour of Sri
Lanka](/wiki/Indian_cricket_team_in_Sri_Lanka_in_2008 "Indian cricket team in
Sri Lanka in 2008") in July 2008, Tendulkar needed 177 runs to go past Brian
Lara's record of Test 11,953 runs. However, he failed in all six innings,
scoring a total of 95 runs. India lost the series and his average of 15.83 was
his worst in a Test series with at least three matches.[160]

### Return to form and breaking Brian Lara's record

In the following ODI series against Sri Lanka, Tendulkar was sidelined due to
injury.[161] However, during the following Australia tour of India, he
returned to fitness and form, scoring 13 and 49 in the first Test[162] before
making 88 in the first innings of the second Test, breaking the record for
most number of Test runs held by Brian Lara. He also reached the 12,000 run
mark when he was on 61.[163][164] He described the achievement as the biggest
in 19 years of his career on the day he achieved the record.[165] He made a
fifty in the third Test[166] and 109 in the fourth, as India won the series
2–0 and regained the Border-Gavaskar Trophy.[167]

### ODI and Test Series against England

Tendulkar was again out of the first three ODIs of a seven-match ODI series at
home against England due to an injury, but he made 11 in the fourth ODI[168]
and 50 in the fifth,[169] before the series was called off due to the [2008
Mumbai terrorist attacks](/wiki/2008_Mumbai_terrorist_attacks "2008 Mumbai
terrorist attacks"), the scoreline being 5–0 to India.[170][171]

England returned for a two-match Test series in December 2008, and the first
Test, which was originally planned to be held in Mumbai, was shifted to
Chennai following the terror attacks.[170][171] Chasing 387 for victory in
that match, Tendulkar scored 103 not out and shared a 163-run unbroken fifth
wicket partnership with [Yuvraj Singh](/wiki/Yuvraj_Singh "Yuvraj
Singh").[172] This was his third century in the fourth innings of a Test
match, and the first which resulted in a win.[173] He dedicated this century
to the victims of the Mumbai terror attacks.[174] Tendulkar scored poorly in
the second Test at [Mohali](/wiki/Mohali "Mohali"), which ended in a draw.
India won the series 1–0.[175]

### 2009–2010

See also: [List of highest individual scores in
ODIs](/wiki/List_of_highest_individual_scores_in_ODIs "List of highest
individual scores in ODIs")

In early 2009, India revisited Sri Lanka for five ODIs, as the Pakistan series
had been cancelled due to the security situation in Pakistan and the attacks
in Mumbai.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Tendulkar scored 5, 6 and 7 in the first three
matches, being dismissed [leg before wicket](/wiki/Leg_before_wicket "Leg
before wicket") in all of them, and did not play in the remaining two
matches.[176]

India's next assignment was an away series against New Zealand, consisting of
three Tests and five ODIs. In the ODI series, Tendulkar made an unbeaten 163
in the third match before stomach cramps forced him to end his innings. India
made 392, won the match[177] and eventually won the series 3–1.[178] Tendulkar
made 160 in the first Test, his 42nd Test century, and India won.[179] He made
49 and 64 in the second Test[180] and 62 and 9 in the third, in which play was
halted on the last day due to rain with India needing only two wickets to win.
India won the series 1–0.[181][182]

Tendulkar rested himself for the ODI tour of West Indies,[183] but was back
for the Compaq Cup Tri Series between India, Sri Lanka and New Zealand in
early September 2009. He made 46[184] and 27[185] in the league matches before
notching up 138 in the final, as India made 319 and won by 46 runs.[186] This
was Tendulkar's sixth century in a final of an ODI tournament and his third
consecutive score of over 50 in such finals.[187]

Tendulkar played only one innings in the ICC Champions trophy in South Africa,
scoring 8 against Pakistan as India lost.[188] The next match against
Australia was abandoned due to rain[189] and he was out with a stomach
infection in the third match against the West Indies, as India were
eliminated.[190]

Australia returned for a seven-match ODI series in India in October, and
Tendulkar made 14, 4, 32 and 40 in the first four games.[191] In the fifth
match, with the series tied at 2–2, Australia amassed 350/4 in 50 overs.[192]
Tendulkar made his 45th ODI hundred, a 175 off 141 balls. Just when it seemed
that he would steer India to the large victory target, he tried to scoop a
slower delivery from debutant bowler [Clint McKay](/wiki/Clint_McKay "Clint
McKay") over short fine leg only to be caught by [Nathan
Hauritz](/wiki/Nathan_Hauritz "Nathan Hauritz"), with India needing 19 runs to
win with 18 balls and four wickets left. The Indian tail collapsed, and
Australia won the match by three runs.[193][194] During this match, Tendulkar
also became the first player to reach 17,000 ODI runs,[194][195] and achieved
his personal best against Australia,[196] as well as the third highest score
in a defeat.[197]

In the five-match ODI series against Sri Lanka in 2009–10, Tendulkar scored
69, 43, 96 not out and 8 in the first four matches,[198] with the fifth match
being abandoned as the pitch was deemed unfit and potentially dangerous.[199]
India won the series 3–1.[200] In the Test series that followed, he scored a
100 not out in the first Test, which was drawn, and 40 and 53 in the second
and third Tests respectively as India clinched innings victories in both the
Tests, to win the series 2–0.[201]

Sachin rested himself for the ODI tri-series in Bangladesh in 2010, but played
in the subsequent Test series.[202] He made 105 not out and 16 in the first
Test, and 143 in the second. India won both the Tests.[203][204]

In the [two-Test Series against South
Africa](/wiki/South_African_cricket_team_in_India_in_2009%E2%80%9310 "South
African cricket team in India in 2009–10"), Tendulkar made 7 and 100 in the
first Test.[205] He then scored 106 in the first innings of the second Test,
which was his 47th hundred in Test cricket. It was also his fourth hundred in
successive Tests, and he was the fourth Indian to achieve this feat.[206][207]
In the second match of the subsequent ODI series, Tendulkar scored 200 not
out, becoming the world's first batsman to score a double century in ODI
cricket and breaking the previous highest score of 194 jointly held by
Pakistan's [Saeed Anwar](/wiki/Saeed_Anwar "Saeed Anwar") and Zimbabwe's
[Charles Coventry](/wiki/Charles_Coventry_\(Zimbabwean_cricketer\) "Charles
Coventry \(Zimbabwean cricketer\)").[Note 2]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Tendulkar_goes_to_14%2C000_Test_runs.jpg/600px-
Tendulkar_goes_to_14%2C000_Test_runs.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tendulkar_goes_to_14,000_Test_runs.jpg
"Tendulkar's shot to reach 14,000 Test runs. He was batting against Australia

[](/wiki/File:Tendulkar_goes_to_14,000_Test_runs.jpg "File:Tendulkar goes to

Tendulkar's shot to reach 14,000 Test runs. He was batting against Australia
in October 2010.

### 2011 World Cup and after

From February to April, Bangladesh, India, and Sri Lanka hosted the [2011
World Cup](/wiki/2011_Cricket_World_Cup "2011 Cricket World Cup"). Amassing
482 runs at an average of 53.55 including two centuries, Tendulkar was India's
leading run-scorer for the tournament; only [Tillakaratne
Dilshan](/wiki/Tillakaratne_Dilshan "Tillakaratne Dilshan") of Sri Lanka
scored more runs in the 2011 tournament.[213] India defeated Sri Lanka in the
final.[214] Shortly after the victory, Tendulkar commented that "Winning the
World Cup is the proudest moment of my life. ... I couldn't control my tears
of joy."[215]

**Tendulkar 's results in international matches**[216]  
---  
| Matches | Won | Lost | Drawn | Tied | No result  
Test[217] | 200 | 72 | 56 | 72 | 0 | –  
ODI[218] | 463 | 234 | 200 | – | 5 | 24  
T20I[219] | 1 | 1 | – | – | – | –  
  
India were due to tour the West Indies in June, although Tendulkar chose not
to participate. He returned to the squad in July for India's [tour of
England](/wiki/Indian_cricket_team_in_England_in_2011 "Indian cricket team in
England in 2011").[220] Throughout the tour there was much hype in the media
about whether Tendulkar would reach his 100th century in international cricket
(Test and ODIs combined). However his highest score in the Tests was 91;
Tendulkar averaged 34.12 in the series as England won 4–0 as they deposed
India as the No. 1 ranked Test side.[221][222] The injury Tendulkar sustained
to his right foot in 2001 flared up and as a result he was ruled out of the
ODI series that followed.[221] Tendulkar created another record on 8 November
2011 when he became the first cricketer to score 15,000 runs in Test cricket,
during the opening Test match against the West Indies at the Feroz Shah Kotla
Stadium in New Delhi.[223][224]

[Ian Chappell](/wiki/Ian_Chappell "Ian Chappell") was not happy with Sachin's
performance after India's tour of Australia. He says that Sachin's quest for
his 100th hundred has proved to be a hurdle for the entire team and has
hampered their performance on the Tour of Australia.[225] Former India World
Cup winning captain and all-rounder Kapil Dev has also voiced his opinion that
Sachin should have retired from ODI's after the World Cup.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Former
Australian fast bowler, Geoff Lawson, has said that Sachin has the right to
decide when to quit although he adds that Tendulkar should not delay it for
too long.[226] The selection committee of BCCI expectedly included Sachin in
the national Test squad for the upcoming series against New Zealand commencing
in August 2012.[227]

#### 100th international century

Tendulkar scored his 100th international hundred on 16 March 2012, at Mirpur
against Bangladesh in the Asia Cup.[228] He became the first person in history
to achieve this feat, which was also his first ODI hundred against Bangladesh.
He said "It's been a tough phase for me ... I was not thinking about the
milestone, the media started all this, wherever I went, the restaurant, room
service, everyone was talking about the 100th hundred. Nobody talked about my
99 hundreds. It became mentally tough for me because nobody talked about my 99
hundreds."[229] Despite Tendulkar's century, India failed to win the match
against Bangladesh, losing by 5 wickets.[230]

#### Return To Ranji Trophy

After being bowled out in three similar instances against New Zealand and
hitting a slump in form, Tendulkar returned to the Ranji Trophy to get back
some form ahead of the England Series at home,[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] in a
match for Mumbai against Railways on 2 November 2012. This was his first Ranji
Trophy match since 2009. He scored 137 off 136 balls, with 21 fours and 3
sixes, to take his team to 344 for 4 at stumps on day one.[231]

However, because of a poor form in the first two Tests in the series against
England, and India being humiliated in the second match of that series by 10
wickets on 26 November 2012,[232] some people have started to question his
place in the Indian team. A report by _[The Hindustan
Times](/wiki/The_Hindustan_Times "The Hindustan Times")_ said that Tendulkar
had a discussion with the national chief selector [Sandeep
Patil](/wiki/Sandeep_Patil "Sandeep Patil"), in which he said that he would
leave it to the selectors to decide on his future as he is not getting any
runs.[233] This speculation, however, was later considered to be
false.[234][235]

Then he decided to play in the knockout stage of the [2012-13 Ranji
Trophy](/wiki/2012-13_Ranji_Trophy "2012-13 Ranji Trophy"). He scored 108 in
the quarter final against [Baroda](/wiki/Baroda_cricket_team "Baroda cricket
team") before being bowled by [Murtuja Vahora](/wiki/Murtuja_Vahora "Murtuja
Vahora"), where Sachin was involved in a 234-run partnership with opener
[Wasim Jaffer](/wiki/Wasim_Jaffer "Wasim Jaffer") (150) for the 3rd wicket at
[Wankhede Stadium](/wiki/Wankhede_Stadium "Wankhede Stadium").[236]
[Mumbai](/wiki/Mumbai_cricket_team "Mumbai cricket team") eventually piled on
645/9 and won on 1st innings lead.[237] In the semi final against
[Services](/wiki/Services_cricket_team "Services cricket team") at Palam A
Ground, with [Mumbai](/wiki/Mumbai_cricket_team "Mumbai cricket team") reeling
at 23/3, Sachin scored 56 from 75 balls and had an 81-run 4th wicket
partnership with [Abhishek Nayar](/wiki/Abhishek_Nayar "Abhishek Nayar")
(70),[238] and Mumbai eventually won on 1st innings lead after the match went
into the sixth day due to rain delays.[239] In the final against
[Saurashtra](/wiki/Saurashtra_cricket_team "Saurashtra cricket team"), he was
run out for 22 following a misunderstanding with [Wasim
Jaffer](/wiki/Wasim_Jaffer "Wasim Jaffer").[240] Mumbai eventually won the
Ranji Trophy 2012–13.[241]

He also played in the [Irani Trophy](/wiki/Irani_Trophy "Irani Trophy") for
Mumbai, where he scored 140* against Rest of India and helped
[Mumbai](/wiki/Mumbai_cricket_team "Mumbai cricket team") to score 409 in
reply to Rest of India's 526. This was also his 81st hundred in first-class
cricket, equalling [Sunil Gavaskar](/wiki/Sunil_Gavaskar "Sunil Gavaskar")'s
Indian record for most first-class hundreds.[242]

### Retirement

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/199Sachin.jpg/220px-199Sachin.jpg)](/wiki/File:199Sachin.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:199Sachin.jpg "Enlarge")

Sachin fielding at 199th Test match in [Eden Gardens](/wiki/Eden_Gardens "Eden
Gardens") (he is seen wearing a hat)

For more details on 200th and final Test match, see [West Indian cricket team
in India in
2013–14](/wiki/West_Indian_cricket_team_in_India_in_2013%E2%80%9314 "West
Indian cricket team in India in 2013–14").

Following poor performance in the 2012 series against England, Tendulkar
announced his retirement from [One Day
Internationals](/wiki/One_Day_International "One Day International") on 23
December 2012, while noting that he will be available for Test
cricket.[243][244] In response to the news, former India captain [Sourav
Ganguly](/wiki/Sourav_Ganguly "Sourav Ganguly") noted that Tendulkar could
have played the up-coming series against
[Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan_cricket_team "Pakistan cricket team"), while [Anil
Kumble](/wiki/Anil_Kumble "Anil Kumble") said it would be "tough to see an
Indian (ODI) team list without Tendulkar's name in it", and Javagal Srinath
mentioned that Tendulkar "changed the way ODIs were played right from the time
he opened in New Zealand in 1994".[245]

After playing a [Twenty20 International](/wiki/Twenty20_International
"Twenty20 International") in 2006 against South Africa, he said that he would
not play the format again.[246] He announced his retirement from the IPL after
his team, [Mumbai Indians](/wiki/Mumbai_Indians "Mumbai Indians"), beat
[Chennai Super Kings](/wiki/Chennai_Super_Kings "Chennai Super Kings") by 23
runs at the Eden Gardens in Kolkata on 26 May to win the [Indian Premier
League 2013](/wiki/Indian_Premier_League_2013 "Indian Premier League
2013").[22] He retired from Twenty20 cricket and limited-overs cricket, after
playing the [2013 Champions League
Twenty20](/wiki/2013_Champions_League_Twenty20 "2013 Champions League
Twenty20") in September–October 2013 in India for Mumbai Indians.[247]

On 10 October 2013 Tendulkar announced that he would retire from all cricket
after the [two-Test series against West Indies in
November](/wiki/West_Indian_cricket_team_in_India_in_2013%E2%80%9314 "West
Indian cricket team in India in 2013–14").[248][249] On his request, the BCCI
arranged that the two matches were played at Kolkata and Mumbai so that the
farewell happened at his home ground.[250][251] He scored 74 runs in his last
Test innings against West Indies, thus failing short by 79 runs to complete
16,000 runs in Test cricket.[23] The [Cricket Association of
Bengal](/wiki/Cricket_Association_of_Bengal "Cricket Association of Bengal")
and the [Mumbai Cricket Association](/wiki/Mumbai_Cricket_Association "Mumbai
Cricket Association") organised events to mark his retirement from the
sport.[252][253] Various national and international figures from cricket,
politics, Bollywood and other fields spoke about him in a day-long _Salaam
Sachin Conclave_ organised by _[India Today](/wiki/India_Today "India
Today")_.[254][255]

In July 2014, he captained the MCC side in the [Bicentenary Celebration
match](/wiki/Bicentenary_Celebration_match "Bicentenary Celebration match") at
[Lord's](/wiki/Lord%27s "Lord's").[256] In December 2014, he was announced
ambassador of the ICC Cricket World Cup 2015 event.[257][258] It is his second
term as he has already held the ambassador of the previous ICC Cricket world
cup 2011.[259][260] So he is heading the ambassador position of the ICC
Cricket world cup in consecutive terms of the cricket world cup (2011 and
2015).

Tendulkar was made the icon player and captain for his home side, the [Mumbai
Indians](/wiki/Mumbai_Indians "Mumbai Indians") in the inaugural [Indian
Premier League](/wiki/Indian_Premier_League "Indian Premier League")
[Twenty20](/wiki/Twenty20 "Twenty20") competition in 2008.[266] As an icon
player, he was signed for a sum of US$1,121,250, 15% more than the second-
highest paid player in the team, [Sanath Jayasuriya](/wiki/Sanath_Jayasuriya
"Sanath Jayasuriya").[267]

In 2010 edition of Indian Premier League, Mumbai Indians reached the final of
the tournament. Tendulkar made 618 runs in 14 innings during the tournament,
breaking [Shaun Marsh](/wiki/Shaun_Marsh "Shaun Marsh")'s record of most runs
in an IPL season. He was declared player of the tournament for his performance
during the season. He also won Best Batsman and Best Captain awards at [2010
IPL Awards](/wiki/2010_Indian_Premier_League#IPL_Awards_2010 "2010 Indian
Premier League") ceremony.[268] Sachin has scored more than 500 runs in IPL in
two different seasons as a captain.[269]

Sachin Tendulkar captained Mumbai Indians in 4 league matches of second
edition of the league. He scored 68 in the first match and 48 against Guyana.
But Mumbai Indians failed to qualify for semifinals after losing the initial
two matches. Tendulkar scored 135 runs.[270]

In the 2011 IPL, against [Kochi Tuskers Kerala](/wiki/Kochi_Tuskers_Kerala
"Kochi Tuskers Kerala"), Tendulkar scored his maiden Twenty20 hundred. He
scored 100 not out off 66 balls. In 51 matches in the IPL Tendulkar has scored
1,723 runs, making him the second-highest run-scorer in the competition's
history.[271] In 2013, Sachin retired from [Indian Premier
League](/wiki/Indian_Premier_League "Indian Premier League") and currently in
2014 he is appointed as the Mumbai Indian Team's 'Icon'.[272]

## Playing style

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Tendulkar_shot.JPG/220px-
Tendulkar_shot.JPG)](/wiki/File:Tendulkar_shot.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Tendulkar_shot.JPG "Enlarge")

Tendulkar plays a wristy leg-side flick

Tendulkar is [cross-dominant](/wiki/Cross-dominance "Cross-dominance"): he
bats, bowls and throws with his right hand, but writes with his left
hand.[273][274] He also practices left-handed throws at the nets on a regular
basis. [Cricinfo](/wiki/Cricinfo "Cricinfo") columnist [Sambit
Bal](/wiki/Sambit_Bal "Sambit Bal") has described him as the "most wholesome
batsman of his time".[1] His batting is based on complete balance and poise
while limiting unnecessary movements and flourishes. He appears to show little
preference for the slow and low wickets which are typical in India, and has
scored many centuries on the hard, bouncy pitches in South Africa and
Australia.[1] He is known for his unique punch style of hitting the ball over
square. He is also renowned for his picture-perfect straight drive, often
completed with no follow-through. The straight drive is often said to be his
favourite shot.[275] In 2008, [Sunil Gavaskar](/wiki/Sunil_Gavaskar "Sunil
Gavaskar"), in an article he wrote in the AFP, remarked that "it is hard to
imagine any player in the history of the game who combines classical technique
with raw aggression like the little champion does".[276]

[Sir Donald Bradman](/wiki/Sir_Donald_Bradman "Sir Donald Bradman"),
considered by many as the greatest batsman of all time, considered Tendulkar
to have a batting style similar to his. In his biography, it is stated that
"Bradman was most taken by Tendulkar's technique, compactness and shot
production, and had asked his wife to have a look at Tendulkar, having felt
that Tendulkar played like him. Bradman's wife, Jessie, agreed that they did
appear similar."[277][278]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Master_Blaster_at_work.jpg/220px-
Master_Blaster_at_work.jpg)](/wiki/File:Master_Blaster_at_work.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Master_Blaster_at_work.jpg "Enlarge")

Tendulkar at the crease, getting ready to face a delivery

Former Australian cricket team coach [John
Buchanan](/wiki/John_Buchanan_\(cricketer,_born_1953\) "John Buchanan
\(cricketer, born 1953\)") voiced his opinion that Tendulkar had become
susceptible to the short ball early in his innings because of a lack of
footwork.[279] Buchanan also believes Tendulkar has a weakness while playing
left-arm pace.[279] He was affected by a series of injuries since 2004. Since
then Tendulkar's batting has tended to be less attacking. Explaining this
change in his batting style, he has acknowledged that he is batting
differently because, firstly, no batsman can bat the same way for the entire
length of a long career and, secondly, he is a senior member of the team now
and thus has more responsibility. During the early part of his career, he was
a more attacking batsman and frequently scored centuries at close to a run a
ball. [Ian Chappell](/wiki/Ian_Chappell "Ian Chappell"), former Australian
player, remarked in 2007 that "Tendulkar now, is nothing like the player he
was when he was a young bloke".[280]

Tendulkar has incorporated several modern and unorthodox strokes into his
repertoire, including the paddle sweep, the scoop over short fine leg and the
slash to third man over the slips' heads, over the last seven or eight years.
He is often praised for his ability to adapt to the needs of his body and yet
keep scoring consistently.[281]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Sachin_Tendulkar_bowling_right-
arm_leg-spin_26_January_2008.JPG/220px-Sachin_Tendulkar_bowling_right-arm_leg-
spin_26_January_2008.JPG)](/wiki/File:Sachin_Tendulkar_bowling_right-arm_leg-
spin_26_January_2008.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Sachin_Tendulkar_bowling_right-arm_leg-spin_26_January_2008.JPG
"Enlarge")

Tendulkar has taken 201 wickets across all three formats of the international
game.

While Tendulkar is not a regular bowler, he can bowl [medium
pace](/wiki/Medium_pace "Medium pace"), [leg spin](/wiki/Leg_spin "Leg spin"),
and [off spin](/wiki/Off_spin "Off spin"). He often bowls when two batsmen of
the opposite team have been batting together for a long period, as he can
often be a useful partnership breaker.[282] With his bowling, he has helped
secure an Indian victory on more than one occasion.[283] He has taken 201
international wickets – 46 in Tests, 154 in ODIs where he is India's tenth
highest wicket taker, and one wicket in [Twenty20
Internationals](/wiki/Twenty20_International "Twenty20 International").[284]

## Fan following

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/A_Cricket_fan_at_the_Chepauk_stadium%2C_Chennai.jpg/170px-
A_Cricket_fan_at_the_Chepauk_stadium%2C_Chennai.jpg)](/wiki/File:A_Cricket_fan_at_the_Chepauk_stadium,_Chennai.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:A_Cricket_fan_at_the_Chepauk_stadium,_Chennai.jpg "Enlarge")

[Sudhir Kumar Chaudhary](/wiki/Sudhir_Kumar_Chaudhary "Sudhir Kumar
Chaudhary"), a fan of Tendulkar who earned the privilege of tickets to all of
India's home games

Tendulkar's consistent performances earned him a fan following across the
globe, including amongst Australian crowds, where Tendulkar has consistently
scored centuries.[64] One of the most popular sayings by his fans is "Cricket
is my religion and Sachin is my God".[285] _[Cricinfo](/wiki/Cricinfo
"Cricinfo")_ mentions in his profile that "... Tendulkar remains, by a
distance, the most worshipped cricketer in the world."[1] During the
Australian tour of India in 1998 [Matthew Hayden](/wiki/Matthew_Hayden
"Matthew Hayden") said "I have seen God. He bats at no. 4 in India in
Tests."[286] However, on God, Tendulkar himself is reported to have said "I am
not God of cricket. I make mistakes, God doesn't."[287] Tendulkar made a
special appearance in the [Bollywood](/wiki/Bollywood "Bollywood") film
[_Stumped_](/wiki/Stumped_\(film\) "Stumped \(film\)") in 2003, appearing as
himself.[288]

There have been many instances when Tendulkar's fans have undertaken extreme
activities over his dismissal in the game. As reported by many Indian
newspapers, a person [hanged himself](/wiki/Suicide "Suicide") due to distress
over Tendulkar's failure to reach his 100th century.[289]

At home in [Mumbai](/wiki/Mumbai "Mumbai"), Tendulkar's fan following has
caused him to lead a different lifestyle. [Ian Chappell](/wiki/Ian_Chappell
"Ian Chappell") has said that he would be unable to cope with the lifestyle
Tendulkar was forced to lead, having to "wear a wig and go out and watch a
movie only at night".[280] In an interview with Tim Sheridan, Tendulkar
admitted that he sometimes went for quiet drives in the streets of Mumbai late
at night when he would be able to enjoy some peace and silence.[290] Tendulkar
has a presence in the popular social networking site Twitter with the user
name `sachin_rt`, since May 2010.[291]

Sachin Tendulkar is the leading run scorer in Tests, with 15,921 runs, as well
as in One-Day Internationals, with 18,426 runs.[1] He is the only player to
score more than 30,000 runs in all forms of international cricket (Tests, ODIs
and Twenty20 Internationals).[5] He is the 16th player and the first Indian to
score 50,000 runs in all forms of domestic and international recognised
cricket ([First-class](/wiki/First-class_cricket "First-class cricket"), [List
A](/wiki/List_A_cricket "List A cricket") and
[Twenty20](/wiki/Twenty20_cricket "Twenty20 cricket")). He achieved this feat
on 5 October 2013, during a [Champions League
Twenty20](/wiki/2013_Champions_League_Twenty20 "2013 Champions League
Twenty20") match for his [IPL](/wiki/Indian_Premier_League "Indian Premier
League") team [Mumbai Indians](/wiki/Mumbai_Indians "Mumbai Indians") against
[Trinidad and Tobago](/wiki/Trinidad_and_Tobago_cricket_team "Trinidad and
Tobago cricket team").[292][293][294]

He also holds the record of the highest number of centuries in both Tests (51)
and ODIs (49) as well as in Tests and ODIs combined (100). On 16 March 2012,
Tendulkar scored his 100th international hundred. It came against
[Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh_cricket_team "Bangladesh cricket team") in the
league matches of [Asia Cup 2012](/wiki/2012_Asia_Cup "2012 Asia Cup").[295]
He is also the only player to score fifty centuries in Test cricket,[296] and
the first to score fifty centuries in all international cricket
combined.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] He also holds the world record for playing the
highest number of Test matches (200)[297] and ODI matches (463).[298]
Tendulkar has been part of most wins by an Indian in both [Test
cricket](/wiki/Test_cricket "Test cricket") with 72 wins and
[ODIs](/wiki/One_Day_International "One Day International") with 234 wins and
is third in the world in ODI victories after [Ricky
Ponting](/wiki/Ricky_Ponting "Ricky Ponting") (262 wins), [Mahela
Jayawardene](/wiki/Mahela_Jayawardene "Mahela Jayawardene") (241
wins).[299][300]

Tendulkar has scored over 1000 runs in a calendar year in ODIs 7 times, and in
1998 he scored 1,894 runs, the record for the highest number of runs scored by
any player in a single calendar year for One-Day Internationals.[298] He is
the first male cricketer to score a double-century in one-day cricket.[210]

He has been [Man of the Match](/wiki/Man_of_the_Match "Man of the Match") 13
times in Test matches and [Man of the Series](/wiki/Man_of_the_Series "Man of
the Series") four times, out of them twice in the [Border-Gavaskar
Trophy](/wiki/Border-Gavaskar_Trophy "Border-Gavaskar Trophy") against
[Australia](/wiki/Australian_cricket_team "Australian cricket team").[301] The
performances earned him respect from Australian cricket fans and players.[64]
Similarly he has been [Man of the Match](/wiki/Man_of_the_Match "Man of the
Match") 62 times in One day International matches and [Man of the
Series](/wiki/Man_of_the_Series "Man of the Series") 15 times.[298] He became
the first batsman to score 12,000, 13,000, 14,000 and 15,000 runs in Test
cricket,[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] having also been the third batsman and the
first Indian to pass 11,000 runs in that form of the game.[302] He was also
the first player to score 10,000 runs in one-day internationals,[303] and also
the first player to cross every subsequent 1000-run mark that has been crossed
in ODI cricket history.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] In the fourth Test of the [2008–09 Border-
Gavaskar Trophy](/wiki/Australian_cricket_team_in_India_in_2008%E2%80%9309
"Australian cricket team in India in 2008–09") against Australia at Nagpur on
6 November 2008, Tendulkar surpassed Australia's [Allan
Border](/wiki/Allan_Border "Allan Border") to become the player to cross the
50-run mark the most number of times in Test cricket history,[304] and also
the second ever player to score 11 Test centuries against Australia, tying
with [Sir Jack Hobbs](/wiki/Sir_Jack_Hobbs "Sir Jack Hobbs") of England more
than 70 years previously.[305] On 8 November 2011, Tendulkar became the first
batsman to score 15,000 runs in Test Cricket.[306]

Tendulkar has consistently done well in [Cricket World
Cups](/wiki/Cricket_World_Cup "Cricket World Cup"). He was the highest run
scorer of the [1996 Cricket World Cup](/wiki/1996_Cricket_World_Cup "1996
Cricket World Cup") with a total of 523 runs and also of the [2003 Cricket
World Cup](/wiki/2003_Cricket_World_Cup "2003 Cricket World Cup") with 673
runs.[307] After his century against England during group stages of [2011
Cricket World Cup](/wiki/2011_Cricket_World_Cup "2011 Cricket World Cup"), he
became the player to hit most number of centuries in Cricket World Cups with
six centuries and the first player to score 2000 runs in World Cup
cricket.[308][309]
