### National honours

  * 1994 – [Arjuna Award](/wiki/Arjuna_Award "Arjuna Award"), by the Government of India in recognition of his outstanding achievement in sports.[310]
  * 1997–98 – [Rajiv Gandhi Khel Ratna](/wiki/Rajiv_Gandhi_Khel_Ratna "Rajiv Gandhi Khel Ratna"), India's highest honour given for achievement in sports.[311]
  * 1999 – [![IND Padma Shri BAR.png](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/IND_Padma_Shri_BAR.png/30px-IND_Padma_Shri_BAR.png)](/wiki/File:IND_Padma_Shri_BAR.png) [Padma Shri](/wiki/Padma_Shri "Padma Shri"), India's fourth highest civilian award.[312]
  * 2001 – [Maharashtra Bhushan Award](/wiki/Maharashtra_Bhushan_Award "Maharashtra Bhushan Award"), Maharashtra State's highest Civilian Award.[313]
  * 2008 – [![IND Padma Vibhushan BAR.png](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/IND_Padma_Vibhushan_BAR.png/30px-IND_Padma_Vibhushan_BAR.png)](/wiki/File:IND_Padma_Vibhushan_BAR.png) [Padma Vibhushan](/wiki/Padma_Vibhushan "Padma Vibhushan"), India's second highest civilian award.[314]
  * 2014 – [![Bharat Ratna Ribbon.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Bharat_Ratna_Ribbon.svg/30px-Bharat_Ratna_Ribbon.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Bharat_Ratna_Ribbon.svg) [Bharat Ratna](/wiki/Bharat_Ratna "Bharat Ratna"), India's highest civilian award.[14][15]

### Other honours

  * 1997 – [Wisden Cricketer of the Year](/wiki/Wisden_Cricketer_of_the_Year "Wisden Cricketer of the Year").[315]
  * 2002 – In commemorating Tendulkar's feat of equalling [Don Bradman](/wiki/Don_Bradman "Don Bradman")'s 29 centuries in Test Cricket, automotive company [Ferrari](/wiki/Ferrari "Ferrari") invited him to its paddock in [Silverstone](/wiki/Silverstone_Circuit "Silverstone Circuit") on the eve of the [British Grand Prix](/wiki/British_Grand_Prix "British Grand Prix") on 23 July, to receive a [Ferrari 360 Modena](/wiki/Ferrari_360_Modena "Ferrari 360 Modena") from the F1 world champion [Michael Schumacher](/wiki/Michael_Schumacher "Michael Schumacher").[316]
  * 2003 – Player of the tournament in [2003 Cricket World Cup](/wiki/2003_Cricket_World_Cup "2003 Cricket World Cup").[111]
  * 2004, 2007, 2010 – [ICC World ODI XI](/wiki/ICC_Awards "ICC Awards").[317]
  * 2009, 2010, 2011 – [ICC World Test XI](/wiki/ICC_Awards "ICC Awards").
  * 2010 – Outstanding Achievement in Sport and the Peoples Choice Award at [The Asian Awards](/wiki/The_Asian_Awards "The Asian Awards") in London.[318]
  * 1998, 2010 – [Wisden Leading Cricketer in the World](/wiki/Wisden_Leading_Cricketer_in_the_World "Wisden Leading Cricketer in the World").[319]
  * 2010 – ICC Award-Sir Garfield Sobers trophy for cricketer of the year.[16][320]
  * 2010 – [LG People's Choice Award](/wiki/ICC_Awards "ICC Awards").[321]
  * 2010 – Made an Honorary [group captain](/wiki/Group_captain "Group captain") by the [Indian Air Force](/wiki/Indian_Air_Force "Indian Air Force").[18]
  * 2011 – BCCI Cricketer of the Year award.[322]
  * 2011 – Castrol Indian Cricketer of the Year award.[323]
  * 2012 – Wisden India Outstanding Achievement award.[324]
  * 2012 – Honorary Life Membership of [Sydney Cricket Ground](/wiki/Sydney_Cricket_Ground "Sydney Cricket Ground") (SCG)[325][326]
  * 2012 – [Honorary Member of the Order of Australia](/wiki/Order_of_Australia#Honorary_awards "Order of Australia"), given by the Australian government.[19][20]
  * 2013 – [Indian Postal Service](/wiki/Indian_Postal_Service "Indian Postal Service") released a stamp of Tendulkar and he became the second Indian after [Mother Teresa](/wiki/Mother_Teresa "Mother Teresa") to have such stamp released in their lifetime.[327]
  * 2017 – [The Asian Awards](/wiki/The_Asian_Awards "The Asian Awards") Fellowship Award at the 7th Asian Awards.

## Personal life

### Family

On 24 May 1995, Tendulkar married Anjali Mehta (b. 1967), a
[paediatrician](/wiki/Paediatrician "Paediatrician"), whom he had first met in
1990.[328][329][330] They have a daughter and a son, Arjun, whose skills in
cricket as a teenager have been receiving attention.[331][332]

### Beliefs

Tendulkar is a practising [Hindu](/wiki/Hindu "Hindu"). He is a devotee of the
deity [Ganesha](/wiki/Ganesha "Ganesha") and was a disciple of the
[guru](/wiki/Guru "Guru") [Sathya Sai Baba](/wiki/Sathya_Sai_Baba "Sathya Sai
Baba") of [Puttaparthi](/wiki/Puttaparthi "Puttaparthi"), whom he visited on
several occasions.[333][334][335] In 1997, Tendulkar captained the Indian
National side, playing against a World Eleven team, in the Unity Cup which was
held at the [Sri Sathya Sai Hill View
Stadium](/wiki/Sri_Sathya_Sai_Hill_View_Stadium "Sri Sathya Sai Hill View
Stadium") in Puttaparthi, in Baba's presence.[336][337] The death of Sai Baba
on Tendulkar's 38th birthday caused him to cancel his celebrations.[338][339]
The cricketer is also known to celebrate [Ganesh
Chaturthi](/wiki/Ganesh_Chaturthi "Ganesh Chaturthi") at home and frequently
visits temples during night when it is calm and quiet.[340][341]

### Business interests

Tendulkar's popularity has led him to be a pioneer in India on cricket
business dealings when he signed a record sports management deal with
[WorldTel](/wiki/WorldTel "WorldTel") in 1995, the value of the deal being ₹30
crore (US$4.7 million) over five years.[342][343] His next contract with
WorldTel in 2001 was valued at ₹80 crore (US$12 million) over five years.[344]
In 2006, he signed a contract with [Saatchi and
Saatchi](/wiki/Saatchi_and_Saatchi "Saatchi and Saatchi")'s ICONIX valued at
₹180 crore (US$28 million) over three years.[345]

Tendulkar has opened two restaurants: _Tendulkar 's_[346]
([Colaba](/wiki/Colaba "Colaba"), [Mumbai](/wiki/Mumbai "Mumbai")) and _Sachin
's_[347] ([Mulund](/wiki/Mulund "Mulund"), [Mumbai](/wiki/Mumbai "Mumbai"))
and [Bangalore](/wiki/Bangalore "Bangalore"). Sachin owns these restaurants in
partnership with Sanjay Narang of Mars Restaurants.

Tendulkar co-owns the [Kochi ISL team](/wiki/Kochi_ISL_team "Kochi ISL team")
in the [Indian Super League](/wiki/Indian_Super_League "Indian Super League")
[Football](/wiki/Football "Football") in association with [PVP
Ventures](/wiki/PVP_Ventures "PVP Ventures") owned by [Prasad V
Potluri](/wiki/Prasad_V_Potluri "Prasad V Potluri"). The team has been named
as [Kerala Blasters](/wiki/Kerala_Blasters_FC "Kerala Blasters FC") after his
nickname "Master Blaster".[348][349][350] He also jointly owns the badminton
team [Bengaluru Blasters](/wiki/Bengaluru_Blasters "Bengaluru Blasters") which
participates in the [Premier Badminton League](/wiki/Premier_Badminton_League
"Premier Badminton League").

In 2013, Tendulkar was listed at 51st position in [Forbes' list of world's
highest-paid athletes](/wiki/Forbes%27_list_of_world%27s_highest-paid_athletes
"Forbes' list of world's highest-paid athletes"), with his total earnings
estimated to be USD 22 million.[351] In October 2013, the net worth of
Tendulkar was estimated at USD 160 million by Wealth X, making him India's
wealthiest cricket player.[352][353]

### Commercial endorsements

Sachin Tendulkar has been sponsored by several brands throughout his career
including [Boost](/wiki/GlaxoSmithKline "GlaxoSmithKline")
(1990–present),[354] [Pepsi](/wiki/Pepsi "Pepsi") (1992–2009),[355] Action
Shoes (1995–2000),[356] [MRF](/wiki/Madras_Rubber_Factory "Madras Rubber
Factory") (1999–2009),[357] [Adidas](/wiki/Adidas "Adidas") (2000–10),
[Britannia](/wiki/Britannia_Industries "Britannia Industries") (2001–07),[358]
[Fiat Palio](/wiki/Fiat_Palio "Fiat Palio") (2001–03),[359]
[TVS](/wiki/TVS,_India "TVS, India") (2002–05),[360] [ESPN Star
Sports](/wiki/ESPN_Star_Sports "ESPN Star Sports") (2002–present),[361]
[Sunfeast](/wiki/ITC_Limited "ITC Limited") (2007–13),[362]
[Canon](/wiki/Canon_\(company\) "Canon \(company\)") (2006–09),[363]
[Airtel](/wiki/Bharti_Airtel "Bharti Airtel") (2004–06),[364]
[Reynolds](/wiki/Newell_Rubbermaid "Newell Rubbermaid") (2007–present),[365]
G-Hanz (2005–07),[366] [Sanyo BPL](/wiki/Sanyo "Sanyo") (2007–present),[367]
[Toshiba](/wiki/Toshiba "Toshiba") (2010–present),[368] [Colgate-
Palmolive](/wiki/Colgate-Palmolive "Colgate-Palmolive"),[369]
[Philips](/wiki/Philips "Philips"),[369] [VISA](/wiki/Visa_\(company\) "Visa
\(company\)"),[369] [Castrol India](/wiki/Castrol_India "Castrol India")
(2011–12),[370] Ujala Techno Bright,[371] [Coca-Cola](/wiki/Coca-Cola "Coca-
Cola") (2011–13)[372] and [Musafir.com](/wiki/Musafir.com "Musafir.com")
(2013–present).[373]

He has also been a spokesperson for [National Egg Coordination
Committee](/wiki/National_Egg_Coordination_Committee "National Egg
Coordination Committee") (2003–05),[374] AIDS Awareness Campaign (2005)[375]
and [Luminous
India](/w/index.php?title=Luminous_Power_Technologies&action=edit&redlink=1
"Luminous Power Technologies \(page does not exist\)") (2010–present).[376]

### Rajya Sabha nomination

In April 2012, Tendulkar accepted the [Rajya Sabha](/wiki/Rajya_Sabha "Rajya
Sabha") nomination proposed by the [President of
India](/wiki/President_of_India "President of India") and became the first
active sportsperson and cricketer to have been nominated.[17][377] Former
cricketers [Sanjay Manjrekar](/wiki/Sanjay_Manjrekar "Sanjay Manjrekar"),[378]
[Ajit Wadekar](/wiki/Ajit_Wadekar "Ajit Wadekar"), [Madan Lal](/wiki/Madan_Lal
"Madan Lal")[379] expressed their surprise over this move. He took the oath of
office on 4 June.[380] He refused to take the bungalow allotted to him in New
Delhi calling it "waste of tax payer's money" as he resides in Mumbai.[381] He
met with some controversy over his attendance in Rajya Sabha proceedings.[382]
Tendulkar has also been accused of not using development fund Rajya sabha
members receive.[383]

### Philanthropy

Tendulkar sponsors 200 underprivileged children every year through Apnalaya, a
Mumbai-based NGO associated with his mother-in-law, Annabel Mehta.[384][385] A
request from Sachin on Twitter raised ₹1.02 crore (US$160,000) through
Sachin's crusade against cancer for the Crusade against Cancer
foundation.[386][387] Sachin Tendulkar spent nine hours on the 12-hour Coca-
Cola-NDTV Support My School telethon on 18 September 2011 that helped raise ₹
7 crore – ₹ 2 crore more than the target – for the creation of basic
facilities, particularly toilets for girl students, in 140 government schools
across the country.[388]

### Autobiography

Sachin Tendulkar’s autobiography, _[Playing It My Way](/wiki/Playing_It_My_Way
"Playing It My Way")_ , was released on 6 November 2014. It was listed in the
2016 [Limca Book of Records](/wiki/Limca_Book_of_Records "Limca Book of
Records") for breaking the record for adult hardback pre-publication orders,
with 1,50,289 copies confirmed.[389]
